DOC.HEAD: Black Activist Killed By Mail Bomb
With AM-Judge Explosion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer was killed when a mail bomb exploded in his office Monday, and federal agents said there were ``strong similarities'' to the mail bomb found at an Atlanta courthouse and the mail bomb killing death of a federal judge in Alabama. Robert Robinson, a city alderman and civil rights activist, died of his wounds at 8:25 p.m. while undergoing surgery at Memorial Medical Center about 3{ hours after the 5 p.m. bomb blast, said hospital spokesman Michael Rowan. ``He lost his right arm, his left hand and some upper body tissue and (suffered) severe damage to his legs,'' fellow alderman Floyd Adams said earlier. Robinson was not able to communicate with doctors when he was brought in to the hospital after the blast around 5 p.m., said Jeryl Davis, another hospital spokesman. A mail bomb killed 11th U.S. Circuit of Appeals Judge Robert Vance in Mountain Brook, Ala., on Saturday. Earlier Monday, a bomb mailed to the 11th Circuit in Atlanta was discovered and removed safely. At a news conference late Monday, FBI Special Agent Bob DeLoach said it was ``definitely a possibility'' that white supremacists sent the bomb that killed Robinson. DeLoach and Special Agent William Hinshaw said the FBI is warning lawyers, judges and NAACP activists in Georgia and Alabama to beware of strange packages. Hinshaw also said the FBI has warned the NAACP that the attacks apparently are related to the Aug. 22, 1989, tear-gas bomb mailed to NAACP's Atlanta offices, in which eight people, including a 4-month old child, were injured. Postal Inspector John Paul confirmed that the Postal Service is investigating the Robinson slaying as well as Vance's because Robinson was killed by a bomb that was in a package mailed to his office. Police told the mayor's office that Robinson had ``received a package, similar to what's been happening in Atlanta and Birmingham,'' said Clerk of Council Dyanne Reese. ``The preliminary investigation indicates strong similarities to the other explosive devices,'' FBI Agent Tom Moore said in Birmingham, Ala., where authorities were investigating Vance's assassination. ``The explosive and incendiary device experts from the FBI and postal authorities who were in Birmingham yesterday and in Atlanta today are being flown into Savannah,'' Moore said. Robinson represented the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in a long-running desegregation case against the Savannah school system, said state Rep. Jim Pannell of Savannah. Pannell, who attended the University of Georgia Law School with Robinson, said Robinson was one of the first black students to attend Savannah High School in the 1960s. He said Robinson handled many criminal defense and personal injury cases, but he said he could not recall any which would have supplied a motive for the bombing.
